metadata.title: HSV Forms an HCMV-like Viral Assembly Center in 2 Neuronal Cells

abstract.text: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a neuroinvasive virus that has been used as a model organism 23

for studying common properties of all herpesviruses. HSV induces host organelle 24 rearrangement and forms dispersed assembly compartments in epithelial cells, which 25 complicates the study of HSV assembly. In this study, we show that HSV forms a visually 26 distinct unitary cytoplasmic viral assembly center (cVAC) in both cancerous and primary 27 neuronal cells that concentrates viral structural proteins and is the site of capsid envelopment. 28
The HSV cVAC also concentrates host membranes that are important for viral assembly, such 29

as Golgi-and recycling endosome-derived membranes. Lastly, we show that HSV cVAC 30 formation and/or maintenance depends on an intact microtubule network and a viral tegument 31 protein, pUL51. Our observations suggest that the neuronal cVAC is a uniquely useful model to 32 study common herpesvirus assembly pathways, and cell-specific pathways for membrane 33 reorganization. 34 35 was not certified by peer review)

During studies of the function of the HSV-1 pUL51 tegument protein we observed cell-117 type-specific localization patterns for pUL51 and, most interestingly, organization into a unitary 118 structure that might correspond to a cVAC in cells of the mouse neuronal CAD cell line. To 119 determine whether this pUL51-containing structure in CAD cells might be a cVAC, we tested the 120 localization of other viral structural proteins. CAD cells were infected with HSV-1(F) at high 121 multiplicity of infection (m.o.i) and co-stained for various tegument and glycoproteins. As shown 122 in Figure 1A , we observed a unitary perinuclear cluster of viral proteins in most cells (Figure 1C ) 123 in which at least six viral structural proteins including pUL11, pUL16, pUL51, gD, gE, and gL 124 were concentrated, suggesting the viral protein cluster might be a cVAC. Note that for these 125 viral proteins, not all of them localize to the putative cVAC at the same efficiency, for example, 126 pUL51 almost exclusively concentrate to the cluster, while most of the gD localizes to the 127 cytoplasmic space or cell membrane. To determine whether a similar structure forms in 128 neuronal cells of human origin, we tested in the same way for formation of the putative cVAC in 129 SH-SY5Y cells, a human cancerous neuronal cell line ( Figure 1B ). As expected, a similar 130 putative cVAC is observed in most cells, albeit at a lower frequency ( Figure 1C ). In addition, 131 unlike in CAD cells, where the putative cVAC is composed of numerous small viral protein 132 puncta ( Figure 1A) , the viral protein cluster in SH-SY5Y cells typically appeared as a collection 133 of several large granules ( Figure 1B) . Together, the localization pattern of viral proteins in both 134 CAD and SH-SY5Y cells is different from it in cells of epithelial origin, such as Vero cells (Figure 135 1D), suggesting that the mode of viral component trafficking is cell context-dependent. 136

body_text.text: To examine whether the formation of the putative cVAC is a specific property of HSV-1, we 137 infected CAD cells with an HSV-2 bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC)-derived virus (Figure 138 1E). As expected, a cluster of viral proteins was observed in infected cells, although pUL11 and 139 gD did not completely colocalize with each other within the cluster ( Figure 1E ). 140

body_text.text: To characterize the temporal dynamics of the HSV-1 putative cVAC, CAD and SH-SY5Y cell 141 were subjected to synchronized infection and fixed at various time points after infection. As 142 shown in Figure 1F , the putative cVAC was formed as early as 4 hour-post-infection (h.p.i) and 143 was maintained as late as 15 h.p.i, and its gross morphology showed no obvious change 144 despite the progression of the cytopathic effect (CPE) caused by the infection. body_text.text: Immortalized cell lines often differ from their primary counterparts in many ways. To determine 149 whether formation of a putative cVAC is a peculiarity of immortalized neuronal cells, primary 150 mouse cortical neurons were tested. Cortical neurons from newborn mouse pups were 151 harvested as described in Material and Methods and allowed to differentiate in vitro for 3 days 152 on a layer of primary mouse astrocyte feeder cells. The mixed culture was then infected with 153 HSV-1(F) and fixed 12 h.p.i before being subjected to immunofluorescent microscopy. 154

body_text.text: These results suggest that the formation of a putative cVAC is a property of both primary and 158 immortalized neuronal cells, and may be specific for cells of the neuronal lineage. 159

body_text.text: The viral protein cluster is the site of capsid envelopment. It is well-established that HCMV 160 forms a cVAC in infected cell. The HCMV viral protein cluster is formed around the MTOC 161 (Sanchez et al., 2000) and is the site of capsid envelopment (Gilloteaux and Nassiri, 2000) . For 162 most cell types, the MTOC is formed around centrosome, which can be defined by staining for a 163 centrosome-specific microtubule protein γ-tubulin (Sanchez and Feldman, 2017) . To test the 164 hypothesis that the cluster of viral proteins that were observed in HSV-infected neuronal cells is 165 an HCMV cVAC-like viral assembly compartment, the distribution of viral capsids in relationship 166

First, CAD cells were infected with 167 a recombinant BAC-derived HSV-1 in which the minor capsid protein pUL35 (VP26) was fused 168 with a red fluorescent protein (RFP), and then the localizations of cytoplasmic capsids, viral 169 tegument protein pUL11, and γ-tubulin were determined. As shown in Figure 3A , most 170 cytoplasmic capsids were concentrated within the "clouds" of pUL11 staining, which surrounded 171 the centrosome, suggesting that the viral protein cluster (putative cVAC) is a viral assembly 172

body_text.text: To confirm that capsid envelopment occurs within a unitary structure in CAD cells, transmission 174 electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on infected CAD cells. Whenever more than ten 175 capsids were observed in a microscopy section, most of them were concentrated at one single 176 perinuclear compartment in the cells, in which various stages of enveloping capsids can be 177 identified ( Figure 3B ). Taken together, these results strongly suggest that HSV forms a cVAC at 178 which capsids are enveloped in infected neurons. 179 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted April 23, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.22.055145 doi: bioRxiv preprint HSV putative cVAC is not an autophagosome or aggresome. The double-membrane nature 180 of some structures that were observed in TEM ( Figure 3B ), suggested the possibility that the 181 putative cVAC might instead be an autophagic compartment, as autophagy is a major 182 mechanism of anti-viral response in neuronal cells (Orvedahl et al., 2007) . Autophagy leads to 183 the formation of a double-membrane structure called autophagosome, which engulfs cellular 184 components and intracellular pathogens within itself before fusing with lysosomes for 185 degradation (Tanida, 2011, Parzych and Klionsky, 2014) . In mammalian cells, the membranes 186 that form an autophagosome are defined by the incorporation of an autophagy marker LC3 187 to membranes, forming puncta structures ( Figure 4C ). Upon infection, these GFP-LC3 puncta 192

do not appear to concentrate to any subcellular compartment or co-localize with viral tegument 193 protein pUL11 or viral glycoprotein gD, suggesting that the HSV putative cVAC is not a 194 canonical autophagosome. 195

When overexpressed in cells, misfolded proteins can concentrate around the centrosome in a 196 microtubule-dependent manner, which forms a protein aggregation termed the aggresome, with 197 lysosomes concentrated on the outer rim (Johnston et al., 1998) . To examine whether the HSV 198 putative cVAC is instead an aggresome-like degradation compartment, LAMP1, a lysosome 199 marker, was stained in infected SH-SY5Y cells. As shown in Figure 4F , the majority of infected 200 cells has reduced LAMP1 positive structures at 12 h.p.i, and viral tegument protein pUL11 does 201 not particularly co-localize or form organized spatial structures with LAMP1 puncta, suggesting 202 that HSV putative cVAC is a bona fide viral assembly site. Interestingly, we also noticed that a 203 minor population of infected cells have shown distinct LAMP1 localization patterns:(i) pUL11 204 puncta rimming around one large intense LAMP1 aggregate (Figure 4G) , and (ii) co-localization 205 between pUL11 and LAMP1 ( Figure 4H ). To examine whether these two patterns represent 206 intermediate stages of HSV cVAC formation, infected SH-SY5Y cells were fixed at various time 207 points, co-stained for pUL11 and LAMP1, and counted for the number of cells exhibiting each 208 distinct pattern. The proportion of cells that showed no association between pUL11 and LAMP1 209 increased with time, while those that showed either of the two patterns of association decreased 210 as infection progressed (Figure 4I ), suggesting that association of the cVAC with LAMP1 211 represents early stages of lysosome morphology alteration by HSV infection. 212 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. (Das et al., 2007) . To elucidate the spatial relationship of Golgi-218 derived membrane and the HSV cVAC in neuronal cells, infected CAD and SH-SY5Y cells were 219 co-stained for Golgi membrane markers GM130 (cis-Golgi) or Golgin97 (trans-Golgi) along with 220 viral tegument protein pUL51. As shown in Figure 5 , membranes positive for GM130 221 concentrate at the same place as pUL51 in infected cells. Interestingly, in SH-SY5Y cells, 222 GM130 positive membranes were observed to form a tubular structure partially or completely 223
surrounding, but not coinciding with pUL51 staining. 224

In infected SH-SY5Y cell, Golgin97 positive membranes also concentrated at the same 225 subcellular compartment as the HSV cVAC, however, individual Golgin97 puncta did not co-226 localize with pUL51 puncta ( Figure 5F ). This is consistent with our observation of infected Vero 227 cells, in which pUL51 and Golgi membranes localized in adjacent to each other at multiple 228 dispersed foci ( Figure 5G , white arrowheads), further supporting the hypothesis that the HSV 229 cVAC is where viral assembly occurs. 230

To further compare the similarity between the HSV cVAC and the HCMV cVAC, a fluorescent 231 protein fused with an ER-localizing signal (Denecke et al., 1992 ) was expressed in CAD or SH-232 SY5Y cells to mark ER membranes before the infection. Nocodazole causes cell type-specific growth defect. Since nocodazole profoundly disrupts 290 HSV cVAC formation, its net consequence, namely viral production, was investigated by single-291 step growth (SSG) assays. As shown in Figure 8A , viral progeny production was reduced in SH-292 SY5Y cells in a dose-dependent manner that proportionally correlates with the reduction in 293 cVAC formation, but the same effect was not observed in CAD cells. This trend remained 294 unchanged as late as 24 h.p.i ( Figure 8B ).These results suggest that nocodazole treatment is 295 unable to change certain aspects of the HSV assembly compartment in CAD cells even if this 296 compartment is no longer concentrated at one single region in the cell. Thus, we hypothesized 297 that in nocodazole treated CAD cells, HSV assembly compartment is still able to form as 298 individual periphery sites, similar to it in epithelial cells. To test this hypothesis, nocodazole-299 treated HSV-infected CAD and SH-SY5Y cells were stained for viral protein pUL51 and gE. As 200μM of ciliobrevin D, which was the highest concentration tested, dispersal of Rab11 puncta 308 was only observed in CAD cells ( Figure 9A ). To test whether ciliobrevin D disrupts cVAC 309 formation, CAD cells were synchronously infected with HSV-(F) and treated with ciliobrevin D at 310 3 h.p.i before staining for pUL11 and -tubulin. The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted April 23, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.22.055145 doi: bioRxiv preprint HCMV tegument protein pUL71 was shown to be important for the cVAC formation and viral 344 assembly (Schauflinger et al., 2011 , Meissner et al., 2012 , Womack and Shenk, 2010 . Also, the 345 N-terminus of pUL71 forms a tyrosine-based retrieval motif (Yxxφ), which upon mutation results 346 in the accumulation of pUL71 on the cytoplasmic membrane, in addition to viral assembly defect 347 (Dietz et al., 2018) . The HSV tegument protein pUL51, a homolog of HCMV pUL71, has a 348 conserved N-terminal Yxxφ motif at residue 19-22 (Roller et al., 2014) . Based on these, we 349 hypothesize that the conserved retrieval motif in pUL51 is also essential for the maintenance of 350 HSV cVAC. To test this hypothesis, CAD and SH-SY5Y cells were infected with a mutant HSV 351 of which tyrosine reside in the hypothetical Yxxφ motif was replaced with an alanine 352 (pUL51Y19A). As shown in Figure 10F , cVAC no longer formed in the HSV mutant infected cells. 353
In addition, pUL51 no longer efficiently co-localized with glycoprotein gE (Figure 10 , G and H), 354

suggesting that not only the concentrated HSV cVAC, but also periphery assembly sites were 355 disrupted by the pUL51Y19A mutation. Unsurprisingly, the pUL51Y19A mutation also causes viral 356 growth defect in both CAD and SH-SY5Y cells (Figure 10 , I and J), which is consistent with our 357 hypotheses that (i) viral assembly sites formation is important for efficient viral production, and 358
(ii) pUL51 plays essential role in HSV cVAC formation. 359 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

If so, 393

concentration of viral proteins would be accompanied by recruitment of markers of 394 autophagosomes or lysosomes. However, the autophagy marker LC3 does not concentrate to 395 the cVAC (Figure 4 ), suggesting these membranes are not canonical autophagosomes. Also, 396 the lysosomal marker LAMP1 does not co-localize with viral protein puncta (Figure 4) , 397

suggesting the cVAC is not a degradation compartment that involves lysosome. Combining 398 these two observations with the stability of the cVAC throughout the infection ( Figure 1F ), we 399 conclude that the cVAC is not a canonical degradation compartment. The requirement for cytoskeleton components is also similar between HCMV and HSV. In cells 529 infected with either virus, nocodazole is able to disrupt cVAC morphology (Indran et al., 530 2010) (Figure 7, 8) , suggesting that utilization of the microtubule network is a conserved 531 mechanism for herpesvirus assembly. Also, sensitivity of the HSV cVAC to ciliobrevin D 532

suggests that dynein motors are important for cVAC maintenance (Figure 9 ), as discussed 533 above, however the potential off-target effect of the dynein ATPase inhibitor cannot be 534 We hypothesize that homologous viral proteins might also function similarly in cells infected with 542 HCMV and HSV. pUL71 of HCMV, which is a homolog of HSV pUL51, was shown to be 543 important for viral cytoplasmic envelopment and proper cVAC morphology (Schauflinger et al., 544 2011) . Reciprocally, in this study, we have shown that pUL51 in HSV is also important for cVAC 545 maintenance, as mutations in HSV pUL51 disrupts cVAC formation ( Figure 10F ). Interestingly, 546 although the hypothetical tyrosine-based trafficking motif in the N-terminus of pUL51 is 547 conserved in several herpesviruses and has been shown to be a cytoplasmic retrieval motif in 548 HCMV homolog pUL71 (Dietz et al., 2018) , it is as yet unclear whether the same holds true for 549 HSV. It is possible that the tyrosine residue at position 19 in pUL51 is indeed a trafficking motif, 550 which upon mutation prevents pUL51 from concentrating to the HSV cVAC and, in turns, causes 551 failure in cVAC formation. In this 559 study, we have shown that the formation of the viral assembly compartment is independent of 560 capsid and capsid nuclear egress ( Figure 10D, E) , confirming a tegument-and glycoprotein-561 centric model for organization of HSV assembly centers. Further supporting this model, a 562 mutation in tegument protein pUL51 was able to not only disperse the centralized cVAC, but 563 also disrupt co-localization between viral components ( Figure 10F ), suggesting tegument 564 proteins might be essential for the maintenance of the HSV assembly compartment. we believe that the cultured neuronal cells will be powerful tools to study HSV assembly. 566 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF2.text: Figure S1), ER-derived membranes do not concentrate at the HSV cVAC in either infected cell 234 line but appear to be excluded from the cVAC area.235 Rab11, but not Rab5, is concentrated at the HSV cVAC. Rab family proteins are small 236 GTPases that guide the trafficking of various vesicles in the endosomal/secretory apparatus and 237 contribute to the identity of different cytoplasmic membrane compartments (Stenmark, 2009). 238 Specific Rab family proteins have been shown to play role in the assembly of alpha-and beta-239 herpesviruses. For example, siRNA against Rab5 or Rab11 each can result in more than 10-fold 240 assembly defect for HSV-1 in HeLa cells (Hollinshead et al., 2012), suggesting that both are 241 important for virus production in epithelial cells. Also, certain subsets of Rab family proteins 242 concentrate to the cVAC in HCMV infected cells and contribute to its morphology (Das et al., 243 2007, Das and Pellett, 2011, Lucin et al., 2018, Indran and Britt, 2011). These observations 244

FIGREF3.text: , A, G, D, and K), similar to the 250 observation of others (Hollinshead et al., 2012, Salgado-Polo et al., 2020). Since it is 251 established that Rab5 and Rab11 concentrate to the MTOC (Ullrich et al., 1996), this Rab5/11-252 concentration region in CAD and SH-SY5Y cells likely contains the centrosome. To show that 253 the concentration of Rab5 and Rab11 around the centrosome is actively maintained in a 254 microtubule-dependent manner, uninfected CAD and SH-SY5Y cells were treated with 5µg/ml of 255 a small molecule microtubule polymerization inhibitor nocodazole. At similar concentrations, 256 CAD and SH-SY5Y cells stayed viable under nocodazole treatment, as observed by others (Li 257 et al., 2006, Chen et al., 2014, Ren et al., 2009) and by us (data not shown). After treatment, 258 both Rab5 and Rab11 no longer concentrated at one single compartment (Figure 6, B, E, H, 259 and L), suggesting Rab5 and Rab11 may be transported toward the centrosome on microtubule 260 motors in CAD and SH-SY5Y cells. 261 In both CAD and SH-SY5Y cells, infection with HSV resulted in Rab11 concentration at the 262 cVAC defined by gE staining (Figure 6, I and M). Furthermore, in CAD cells, Rab 5 appeared to 263 be excluded from the cVAC since no overlapping signal was observed (Figure 6C), whereas in 264 SH-SY5Y cells, Rab5 was distributed throughout the cytoplasm, including the cVAC area 265 (

FIGREF4.text: , B, E, H, and L), we hypothesize that the concentration of Rab11 to 270 the cVAC in an HSV infection is also microtubule-dependent. To test this hypothesis, CAD and 271 SH-SY5Y cells were treated with nocodazole three hours after synchronized infection. As shown 272 in Figure 6, J and N, in nocodazole treated HSV infected cells, Rab11 no longer accumulates at 273 a defined concentration; instead, Rab11 puncta disperse throughout the cell, with no obvious 274 localization pattern, suggesting microtubule polymerization is required for Rab11 concentration 275to the HSV cVAC.

FIGREF9.text: formation is not dependent on actin filaments. To rule out the possibility that the 314 cVAC disruption in nocodazole or ciliobrevin D treatment is due to general collapse of the 315 cytoskeleton, infected CAD and SH-SY5Y cells were then treated with cytochalasin B, an actin 316 filament polymerization inhibitor (MacLean-Fletcher and Pollard, 1980). When treated with 317 cytochalasin B, uninfected or infected cells round up similarly to nocodazole treated cells, 318 however, HSV cVAC still forms at the same efficiency in infected cells (Figure S2, A-C), 319 suggesting HSV cVAC formation is not actin dependent. 320 pUL51 plays important role in the maintenance of HSV cVAC morphology. A well-321 established literature has described various viral proteins in HCMV that are essential for proper 322 cVAC morphology and viral production, many of which have homologs with similar functions in 323 HSV. HCMV kinase pUL97 and its HSV homolog pUL13 have important functions in viral 324 nuclear egress (Kato et al., 2006, Cano-Monreal et al., 2009, Marschall et al., 2005, Milbradt et 325 al., 2009, Sharma et al., 2015, DeRussy et al., 2016) and have been implied to play role in viral 326 cytoplasmic assembly (Prichard et al., 2005, Goldberg et al., 2011, Eaton et al., 2014, 327 Gershburg et al., 2015). It was shown that the loss of pUL97 in HCMV results in abnormal cVAC 328 formation (Prichard et al., 2005), however, it was unclear whether it was due to the defect in 329 nuclear egress or the defect in cytoplasmic assembly. To test whether the presence of capsid in 330 the cytoplasm is required for HSV cVAC formation, CAD and SH-SY5Y cells were infected with 331an HSV virus lacking the expression of major capsid protein VP5. As shown inFigure 10D, the 332 HSV cVAC still formed, suggesting viral capsid is not required. Since the more profound role of 333 pUL97 in HCMV and pUL13 in HSV is nuclear lamin network disruption(Kato et al., 2006,  334   Sharma et al., 2015, it is also possible that the viral-induced nuclear membrane alteration is 335 required for the formation of HSV cVAC. To test this hypothesis, CAD and SH-SY5Y cells were 336 infected with an HSV virus lacking the expression of pUL34, a subunit of HSV nuclear egress 337 complex (NEC)(Reynolds et al., 2001). Since pUL34 is a protein that is essential for lamin A/C 338 phosphorylation(Bjerke and Roller, 2006), emerin phosphorylation(Leach et al., 2007), and339 nuclear shape alteration (Vu et al., 2016, Bjerke and Roller, 2006), a UL34-null virus should 340

FIGREF10.text: described an HSV infection-induced structure that concentrates at least six viral 361 structural proteins specifically in neuronal cells. While we have only stained for only six viral 362 structural proteins, they represent core components of at least two viral membrane protein 363 complexes, including the fusion complex that is composed of gD, gB and gH/L (Rodger et al., 364 2001) and a cell-cell spread specific complex gE-gI (Johnson and Feenstra, 1987). All of these 365 proteins have been reported to form stable complexes with other HSV structural proteins, and 366 so it seems highly likely that other interacting viral factors including gM (Crump et al., 2004), 367 gK/pUL20 (Lau and Crump, 2015), pUL7 (Roller and Feters, 2015), VP16 (Johnson et al., 368 1984), and VP22 (Farnsworth et al., 2007) also concentrate at the same structure. This is 369 consistent with the hypothesis that the observed structure is a cVAC at which all of the 370 components necessary for cytoplasmic envelopment are organized. Furthermore, almost all 371 capsid envelopment events were observed concentrating to one region located to one side of 372 the nucleus in CAD cells by TEM imaging (Figure 3). These capsids likely correspond to the 373 capsid concentration in UL35-RFP virus infected cells (Figure 3), where is also where all viral 374 proteins concentrate. Similar concentration of viral proteins and envelopment events have also 375 been observed in other viruses that form cytoplasmic assembly centers, such as HCMV and 376 reovirus (Tenorio et al., 2019). 377 While the viral structural proteins that we have tested all concentrate in the neuronal cVAC, 378 none are exclusively localized to this structure, and they vary considerably in the proportion of 379 the protein found there. pUL11 and pUL51 for example are highly concentrated in the cVAC 380 (Figure 1). In contrast, gD, while concentrated in the cVAC is easily detectable on the cell 381 surface and on membranes throughout the cytoplasm (Figure 1). It is unsurprising that all of the 382 structural proteins have some presence outside of the cVAC, since they must be present in fully 383 assembled egressing virions and as biosynthetic intermediates such as integral membrane 384 proteins in the ER. Furthermore, several of the virion envelope glycoproteins contain plasma 385 membrane retrieval motifs in their cytoplasmic tails and are thought to be retrieved from the 386 plasma membrane and arrive at the site of cytoplasmic envelopment through endosomal 387 trafficking (Alconada et al., 1999, Beitia Ortiz de Zarate et al., 2007, Crump et al., 2004).

FIGREF12.text: 400 and transient co-localization of LAMP1, with virus structural proteins early in infection in some 401 cells. This might reflect an early host antiviral response that inhibits virus production, or it may 402 represent a virus-induced alteration in lysosome organization to promote replication. 403 The formation of a unique cVAC has not previously been reported in HSV infection, but appears 404 to be a constant feature of infection of neuronal cells, as we have observed the cVAC structure 405 in at least two cancerous neuronal cell lines, one of murine origin and one of human origin, and 406 in primary mouse neurons. While it would be of great interest to observe whether a cVAC 407 structure forms in human trigeminal neurons during a natural oral infection as well, such clinical 408 samples would be rare and it is not known how large a subset of these neurons undergo lytic 409 infection (Held and Derfuss, 2011). 410 Since a single HSV cVAC does not form in infected epithelial cells, and since, within the mixed 411 culture of primary neural cells, only neurons, but not astrocytes, allow the formation a cVAC 412 (Figure 2), it is likely that formation of a single cVAC is a specific viral adaptation for infection of 413 neurons. Also, despite that HSV forms cVAC in both CAD and SH-SY5Y cells, there exists 414 considerable variations in their morphology (Figure 1), which suggests the importance of host 415 factors that may vary between human and mouse species or between different neuronal 416 subsets. One factor that might have contributed to the difference between HSV assembly 417 compartment in neurons and epithelial cells is cell polarity. In epithelial cells, cell polarity follows 418 the apical-basolateral axis, while the cell polarity in neurons follows the axon (Bartolini and 419 Gundersen, 2006, Bonifacino, 2014). Since HSV capsids and vesicles that are positive for viral 420 structural proteins move along the microtubule network (Kratchmarov et al., 2012), it is possible 421 that these viral components, despite being transported in the same manner along microtubules, 422 are trafficked to distinct compartments, such as basolateral side in epithelial cells and 423 centralized compartment at cell body in neurons, due to specific cell polarity. Similarly, another 424 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. of HSV assembly compartment difference is the availability of host microtubule 425 components in neurons. This includes as least three non-mutually exclusive aspects: (i) the lack 426 of factors for non-centrosomal microtubule nucleation site in neurons. It was described that 427 Golgi membrane can anchor microtubule minus end and serve as a MTOC in several types of 428 somatic cells (Sanchez and Feldman, 2017), and indeed, in HCMV-infected cells, microtubules 429 preferentially polymerize from Golgi-derived membranes instead of the centrosome (Procter et 430 al., 2018). Since there has been no evidence hitherto suggesting that such alternative MTOC 431 sites can occur efficiently in mammalian neurons (Sanchez and Feldman, 2017), it is possible 432 that the deficiency or absence of alternative microtubule nucleation factor necessitates the 433 centrosome as the viral assembly site in neurons, hence the unitary cVAC. (ii) Different 434 expression level or distribution of certain dynein components or cargo adaptors. Higher 435 eukaryotes encode several isoforms of dynein intermediate and light chains, which are 436 important for cargo specificity (Pfister et al., 2006, Dixit et al., 2008). Also, is has been described 437 that the same trafficking motif of the same protein might utilize different adaptor protein subunits 438 in neurons and epithelial cells (Bonifacino, 2014, Farias et al., 2012). It is possible that viral 439 tegument and glycoproteins can only utilize a certain subset of these dynein motors or cargo 440 adaptors, which in neurons only provides trafficking towards the centrosome while in epithelial 441 cells provides diverse trafficking destinations. (iii) The centrosome in neuronal cells is resistance 442 to viral manipulation. It has been observed that in HSV-infected epithelial cell, centrosome 443 disappears in many cells (Pasdeloup et al., 2013), while in most infected neuronal cells, the 444 centrosome appears to be intact (Figure 3, 7, 9, S2). It is possible that dispersed assembly 445 compartments of HSV in epithelial cells is caused by the loss of centrosome, while in neurons, 446 the stability of the centrosome allows it to out-compete alternative sites and to serve as the 447 major MTOC, which naturally concentrates all viral structural proteins. 448 The organization of host membranes. The identity of the membrane at which HSV 449 cytoplasmic envelopment occurs in epithelial cells is currently controversial, with evidence 450 supporting both trans Golgi and endosomal membranes, but not ER (Lv et al., 2019). The 451 arrangement of host Golgi, ER, and some endosomal membranes in the HSV neuronal cVAC is 452 broadly consistent with previous results derived from epithelial cell studies. ER membranes are 453 not included in the neuronal cVAC (Figure S1). In contrast, cis-and trans-Golgi-derived 454 membranes concentrate to the cVAC but do not completely co-localize with viral structural 455 proteins (Figure 5). This is similar to the previously described localization pattern of Golgi-456 derived membranes in HSV-infected epithelial cells, in which viral capsid and tegument proteins 457 localize adjacent to, and sometimes overlapping with Golgi marker staining (Sugimoto et al., et al., 2012). Hollinshead et al., have shown that some HSV in epithelial cells 459 undergoes envelopment at membranes that are derived from endosomes (Hollinshead et al., 460 2012). Consistent with this idea, we observed concentration of Rab11 endosomes in the cVAC 461 with extensive co-localization between Rab11 and virus structural proteins (Figure 6). 462 Hollinshead and colleagues also showed that Rab5 and Rab11 are important in HSV assembly 463 in HeLa cells (Hollinshead et al., 2012). Rab11 is a recycling endosome marker that has been 464 proposed to play role in the export of HSV cytoplasmic virions (Spearman, 2018, Bucci et al., 465 2014). While concentration of Rab11 at the neuronal cVAC is consistent with a role in virion 466 export, the extensive co-localization between Rab 11 and the viral structural proteins raises the 467 possibility that Rab11 endosomes may be an important site of envelopment. 468 Rab5 is an early endosome marker that, in neurons, retrieves vesicles from both cytoplasmic 469 membrane of the cell body and synaptic membranes from the distal end of axon (Spearman, 470 2018, Bucci et al., 2014). We have observed that Rab5 does not concentrate in the HSV 471 neuronal cVAC, and instead is localized in peripheral puncta, where it co-localizes with some of 472 the cytoplasmic gE (Figure 6C). It is possible that these puncta represent retrieval vesicles that 473 contain viral glycoproteins being trafficked to the cVAC. 474Species specific requirement of microtubule network. The HSV cVAC in cancerous 475neuronal cells forms around the MTOC defined by γ-tubulin staining(Figure 3, 7), suggesting 476 that it is formed and maintained by retrograde transport of membranes and proteins toward the 477 MTOC by microtubule-associated motors. Consistent with this hypothesis, both nocodazole, a 478 microtubule polymerization inhibitor(De Brabander et al., 1976), and ciliobrevin D, a dynein 479 motor ATPase inhibitor(Firestone et al., 2012), are able to disrupt cVAC morphology in CAD 480 cells(Figure 6-9). However, the requirement for an intact microtubule network and, therefore, for 481 a normally formed cVAC for viral assembly in neuronal cell lines is cell-type dependent. 482Nocodazole treatment affects virus production in a dose-dependent manner in SH-SY5Y, but 483 not in CAD cells. This suggests that in CAD cells, despite the dispersal of unitary cVAC around 484 the MTOC, viral proteins are still able to associate with each other to form dispersed, peripheral 485 assembly sites, and indeed we still observed co-localization of the viral structural proteins 486 (Figure 8C). In contrast, in SH-SY5Y cells, tegument proteins and glycoproteins no longer co-487 localize with each other efficiently when microtubule network is disrupted (Figure 8C). The488 mechanistic basis for this discrepancy is unclear, but possibilities include: (i) different 489 sensitivities of the microtubule network to nocodazole. It has been described that herpesviruses 490 can stabilize microtubules via acetylation or de-tyrosination (Wloga et al., 2017, Procter et al., et al., 2013). Thus, a subset of microtubules in CAD cells might be resistant to 492 nocodazole during HSV infection and still promote organization of peripheral assembly sites. (ii) 493 Biosynthetic and retrieval pathways for membrane glycoproteins might differ between these cell 494 types such that localization of assembly proteins to the same membrane compartment might 495 occur without a need for microtubule-dependent trafficking in CAD cells. It is interesting that 496 disruption of the cVAC by nocodazole in CAD cells creates a dispersed assembly apparatus 497 that is morphologically similar to that observed in epithelial cells, and that virus assembly in 498 epithelial cells is not sensitive to nocodazole treatment. Whether the similarities between the 499 assembly compartments in nocodazole-treated CAD cells and untreated epithelial cells are 500 merely superficial or reflective of similar mechanisms of assembly compartment formation is not 501 clear. 502 Similarities and discrepancies between HCMV cVAC and HSV cVAC. It is well-documented 503 that HCMV forms a unitary cVAC in infected cultured fibroblasts (Alwine, 2012) and forms a 504 dense cytoplasmic inclusion in cells from clinical samples (Gilloteaux and Nassiri, 2000). There 505 are many similarities between the cVAC formed by two herpesviruses regarding host membrane 506 arrangement, host cytoskeleton involvement, and viral factor requirement. First, we have 507 observed that Golgi-derived membranes concentrate to the HSV cVAC, similar to the Golgi 508 marker arrangement in HCMV-infected cells (Das et al., 2007, Das and Pellett, 2011), 509 suggesting herpesvirus conserved requirement for Golgi function. On the other hand, the 510 localization pattern of ER membranes in HSV-infected neuronal cells (Figure S1) is similar to 511 the common laboratory strains of HCMV-infected fibroblasts, in which ER membranes mostly 512 retain their natural structure (Zhang et al., 2019). This is different from the ER morphology of 513 wild-type HCMV strain TB40/E-infected cells, in which ER membranes are deformed by dilation 514 and ruffling (Zhang et al., 2019). This strain-specific difference is due to the quick loss of a 515 single gene UL148 (which encodes an ER-modification protein in HCMV strain TB40/E) during 516 the passage of the virus in cell cultures (Zhang et al., 2019). UL148 has no homolog in HSV, 517 thus the resemblance between ER patterns in HSV-infected cells and HCMV-infected cells is 518 not surprising. 519 Other host membrane markers, notably Rab family GTPases, localize to the cVAC of HSV and 520 HCMV in patterns that are consistent with their roles in the vesicle trafficking and in viral 521 assembly. For example, Rab11 participates in the viral assembly of both HSV and HCMV (Hook 522 et al., 2014, Krzyzaniak et al., 2009), and indeed, Rab11 concentrates to the cVAC of both 523 viruses (Das and Pellett, 2011, Das et al., 2007)(Figure 6, I and M). On the other hand, Rab5 is 524

FIGREF13.text: excluded. Inhibition of cVAC formation or maintenance by expression of the dynactin subunit 535 p150Glued CC1 domain, which is a dominant negative inhibitor of dynein motor function, has 536 been demonstrated in HCMV-infected cells (Buchkovich et al., 2010). However, the much 537 shorter lifecycle, and the dynein dependence of early events in infection, make this approach 538 more difficult for HSV. Conversely, small molecule inhibitors like nocodazole and ciliobrevin D 539 also have limitations in assessing the consequences of microtubule disruption in HCMV-infected 540 cells, as cell viability dwindles quickly after treatment. 541

The unitary HSV cVAC in neuronal cells provides 553 great advantages in the study of HSV cytoplasmic assembly, as it allows accessing of 554 phenotypes of mutant viruses that show no obvious morphology change under microscope in 555 epithelial cells, which in turn can be used to answer difficult yet fundamental questions about 556

SH-SY5Y 570 cells (gift from Stevens Lewis at the University of Iowa) were maintained in Opti-MEM 571 supplemented with sodium pyruvate, non-essential amino acid, P/S, and 10% FBS. Primary 572 mouse cerebral cortex neurons and mouse glial feeder cells in primary culture were prepared by 573 a method described previously(Mitchell et al., 2018) with slight modifications. In brief, the 574 cerebral cortex was dissected from wild-type mice at postnatal days 0-1. Tissues of cerebral 575 cortex were taken from the region immediately dorsal to the striatum. The dissected tissues 576 were trypsinized and mechanically dissociated. The cells were plated on 12-mm coverslips 577(thickness No. 0, Carolina Biological Supply, Burlington, NC) in 24-well plates, at the density of 578 10,000 cells per coverslip. The coverslips had previously been seeded with an astrocytic feeder 579 layer at the density of 20,000 cells per coverslip for 7-9 days, prepared from the CA3-CA1 580 region of the wild-type mouse hippocampus at postnatal days 0-1. The cultured neurons were 581 infected with the virus after 3 days in vitro (DIV). All cells were cultured in a humidified incubator 582 at 37°C, with 5% CO2. 583 Animal care and use procedures were approved by the University of Iowa's Institutional Animal 584 Care and Use Committee, and performed in accordance with the standards set by the PHS 585 Policy and The Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (NRC Publications) revised 586 2011. Every effort was made to minimize suffering of the animals. 587 Plasmid and DNA transfection. pcDNA-GFP plasmid was purchased from Addgene (Plasmid 588 #13031). CAD or SH-SY5Y cells were seeded into 24-well tissue culture plates containing glass 589 coverslips at 1x10 5 cells per well 17-24 hs before transfection. Cells were then transfected with 590 X-tremeGENE™ HP DNA Transfection Reagent (Millipore-Sigma) or Lipofectamine® Reagent 591 (Invitrogen) following product protocols. 592 Construction and production of recombinant viruses. The properties of HSV-1(F) virus have 593 been described before (Ejercito et al., 1968). The HSV-1(F) BAC virus was a gift ). These two fragments were assembled together by PCR with a pair of outer primers: fwd 603 primer: 5'-CGGGGCTATATGTGGCTGGGGAGCGCGCCCCGAGGAACAAGCTGAGATG-3'; 604 rev primer: 5'-CTCCGCCTCCGAGGGCGGAACGGCCGCGCGGATCATCTC-3'. Recombinant 605 viruses were rescued by transfecting BAC DNA into Vero or Vero-derived complementing cells. 606 Virus containing mutations in the UL51 gene sequence were amplified on UL51-complementing 607 cells (Roller et al., 2014). HSV-1(F) BAC-derived virus containing deletions in the UL34 gene 608 sequence have been described before (Roller et al., 2010) and were amplified on UL34-609 complementing cells (Roller et al., 2000). The HSV-1(F) VP5-null virus and VP5-complementing 610 cells were kind gifts from Prashant Desai (Desai et al., 1993). HSV-1(F) UL35-RFP BAC virus 611 was a gift from Cornel Fraefel at the University of Zürich (de Oliveira et al., 2008). HSV-2 strain 612 R519-derived BAC virus (bHSV2-BAC38) was a gift from Kening Wang at National Institute of 613 Allergy and Infectious Diseases (Wang et al., 2012). 614 Viral infections When infecting CAD and SH-SY5Y cells, HSV was diluted in the following 615 infection medium: DMEM containing 1% heat-inactivated serum and P/S. In synchronized 616 infection, cells were incubated in the infection medium containing HSV at 4°C for 1h before 617 replacing with warm infection medium to allow viral entry. This medium change is designated as 618 0 h.p.i. For drug treatment, the infection medium was replaced with the same medium 619 containing respective compound (or vehicle only). Stock solutions of nocodazole (AdipoGen), 620 ciliobrevin D (EMD Millipore), and cytochalasin B (AdipoGen) were made in DMSO. For SSG 621 and growth curve experiments, after 4°C incubation and medium replacement, monolayer of 622 confluent cells were incubated at 37°C for 1 h to allow viral entry. Then the monolayer was 623 incubated in a citrate buffer (50 mM sodium citrate, 4 mM KCl, adjusted to pH 3.0 with HCl) for 1 624 min to inactivate residual virus. The cell monolayer was then washed twice in PBS and 625 incubated in infection medium before drug treatment at 3 h.p.i. 626

Transfected or infected cells on 13-mm-diameter 633 coverslips in 24-well tissue culture plates were fixed with 3.7% formaldehyde for 20 minutes 634 before washing with PBS two times. The immunofluorescence (IF) buffer used to dilute 635 antibodies or antiserum is PBS that contains 1% triton X100, 0.5% sodium deoxycholate, 1% 636 egg albumin, and 0.01% sodium azide. Fixed coverslips were first blocked with IF buffer 637 containing 10% human serum before 1 to 2 hs-long primary antibody incubation (with 10%638 human serum) and 1 h secondary fluorescent antibody incubation. The primary antibodies 639 reactive with viral proteins and cellular markers include 1:500 rabbit anti-UL51 antiserum (gift 640 from Joel Baines), 1:500 rabbit anti-UL11 antiserum, 1:500 rabbit anti-UL16 antiserum, 1:500 641 rabbit anti-UL21 antiserum (all three provided by John Wills), 1:1,500 mouse [DL6] anti-gD 642 monoclonal antibody, 1:500 mouse [L4] anti-gL monoclonal antibody (both gifts of Gary Cohen 643 and Roselyn Eisenberg), 1:500 mouse monoclonal anti-gE antibody (Virusys), 1:500 mouse 644 anti-MAP2 antibody (Sigma-Aldrich), 1:500 mouse anti--tubulin antibody (Sigma-Aldrich), 1:500 645 rabbit anti--tubulin antibody (Sigma-Aldrich), 1:500 mouse [H4A3] anti-LAMP1 antibody 646 (DHSB), 1:250 rabbit anti-Rab5 antibody (Abcam), 1:250 rabbit anti-Rab11 antibody (Abcam), 647 1:500 mouse anti-GM130 antibody (BD Bioscience), 1:500 mouse polyclonal anti-Golgin97 648 antibody (Abcam), and 1:500 mouse anti-ß-tubulin antibody (Sigma-Aldrich). Actin filament was 649 stained with 1:1,000 Alexa Flour™ 647 fluorescence conjugated phalloidin (Thermo Fisher 650 Scientific). Nuclei were stained with 1:500 DNA dye Hoechst 33342 (Invitrogen). Stained 651 coverslips were then mounted with ProlLong TM Diamond Antifade Mountant (Invitrogen) and 652 allowed to cure in the dark at room temperature overnight. Confocal images were taken on a 653 Leica DFC7000T confocal microscope equipped with Leica software. Signal patterns of interest 654 were counted by eye. Co-localization efficiency of signals from different channels were 655 measured with FIJI ImageJ software for each cell. 656 Western blot. Cell lysates were separated on SDS-PAGE by size and transferred to 657 nitrocellulose membranes before blocking in 5% nonfat milk plus 0.2% Tween 20 for at least 1 658 h. Then, membranes were probed with either 1:500 rabbit anti-UL51 antiserum, 1:500 mouse 659 anti-VP5 antibody (Biodesign), or 1:250 chicken anti-UL34 antiserum (Reynolds et al., 2001) 660 and visualized by alkaline phosphatase-conjugated secondary antibody.
